de.esoco.lib.datatype

Class Range<T extends java.lang.Comparable<T>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.esoco.lib.datatype.Range<T>
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.Iterable<T>

    public class Range<T extends java.lang.Comparable<T>>
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.Iterable<T>
    A generic implementation for iterable ranges of comparable numeric values. Ranges consist of a start and an end value with a certain step size to increment or decrement values by during iteration. The current implementation supports all standard number types (Integer, Long, Short, Byte, Float, Double, BigInteger, BigDecimal) as well as Character values.

    Ranges are defined with a simple builder pattern: a new instance is created with the static factory methods called from(value) with a start value which also defines the range datatype. Before the range can be used an end value must be defined by invoking either to(Comparable) or toBefore(Comparable) for inclusive or exclusive end values, respectively. The default step size is 1 (one) but a different step size can be set through step(Comparable). Trying to use a range that has no end value will cause a runtime exception to be thrown.

    To support the builder pattern ranges are "effectively" immutable. Effectively means that the range end and step size can only be defined once by calling the respective methods. Invoking these methods again causes an exception to be thrown. There's one limitation: because the step size has a default value of 1 a range on which no step size has been set explicitly still has a mutable step size. Therefore, when defining range constants it is advised to explicitly set the step size even if it is the default value of one.

    Decimal or floating-point datatypes should be used cautiously, especially if fractional steps are used because these may cause non-terminating divisions or rounding errors. Especially binary floating-point types (float, double) may behave unexpected because of the typical binary-to-decimal conversion inaccuracies of these types.

      • getEnd

        public T getEnd()
        Returns the last value of this range. If the range has been defined with toBefore(Comparable) the value returned by this method will be last value before the exclusive end based on the step size.
        Returns:
        The last value

        public T getStart()

        Returns:
        The first value

      • getStep

        public T getStep()
        Returns the step size for iterating over this range. The sign of the returned value will reflect the iteration direction (positive if iterating from lower to higher values, negative for the the other way).
        Returns:
        The step size

        Checks the range direction.
        Returns:
        TRUE if the range values are ordered ascending, FALSE if ordered descending

      • step

        public Range<T> step(T rStep)
        Sets the step size for iteration through this range. The step must always be a positive value. If the range end is lower than the start the step will be automatically applied by subtraction.

        This method can only be invoked once and afterwards this range is effectively immutable. If no explicit value is given a default step size of 1 (one) will be used.

        Parameters:
        rStep - The step size
        Returns:
        This instance for fluent invocations
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the step value is invalid or has already been set

      • stream

        public java.util.stream.Stream<T> stream()
        Returns a stream of the values in this range.
        Returns:
        The stream of range values

      • to

        public Range<T> to(T rEnd)
        Sets the inclusive end value of this range. This method can only be invoked once and afterwards this range is effectively immutable.
        Parameters:
        rEnd - The end value (inclusive)
        Returns:
        This instance for fluent invocations
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the end value has already been set

      • toBefore

        public Range<T> toBefore(T rBefore)
        Sets the exclusive end value of this range. This method can only be invoked once and afterwards this range is effectively immutable. The value returned by getEnd() will be the argument of this method incremented or decremented by the range step depending on the range direction.
        Parameters:
        rBefore - The end value (exclusive)
        Returns:
        This instance for fluent invocations
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the end value has already been set

      • toList

        public java.util.List<T> toList()
        Returns a list that contains all elements of this range.
        Returns:
        A new list containing the range elements
